objects.name: NCSC
objects.description: The UK National Cyber Security Centre authored and published this Malware Analysis Report on COLDSTEEL and provided accompanying YARA detection rules.

objects.name: COLDSTEEL C2 server
objects.description: Public C2 infrastructure used by COLDSTEEL; observed listening on port 443 per report.

objects.description: Public C2 infrastructure used by COLDSTEEL; port not specified in report.

objects.name: COLDSTEEL C2 server

objects.name: newdev.dll (Service DLL for COLDSTEEL)
objects.description: Malicious DLL used by COLDSTEEL to maintain persistence as a Windows service across MileStone2016/2017 variants.

objects.name: dllhost.exe (copied cmd.exe)
objects.description: In some samples, COLDSTEEL copies cmd.exe to this path named dllhost.exe to masquerade and execute commands over a new C2 connection.

objects.name: coldsteel
objects.description: COLDSTEEL is a fully featured Windows Remote Access Tool (RAT) that provides interactive desktop and command-line access. It supports file operations (copy, move, delete, upload/download), takes screenshots, simulates user input (keyboard and mouse), and can run arbitrary commands via cmd.exe. It maintains persistence by creating an autostart Windows service (often impersonating legitimate names like msupdate/msupdate2 and using svchost.exe as the host), and communicates with its C2 over raw TCP (commonly on ports 443, 8843, 8888) using a custom message format that is not HTTPS. Variants include MileStone2016, MileStone2017, and FBI20111024, with MileStone2017 commonly packed using Themida (versions 3.0.5 and 3.1.1) for defense evasion. Earlier variants (MileStone2016, FBI20111024) lack Windows 10 support and implement a custom obfuscation for network contents (byte-wise XOR/add with a 0x1D key). Some variants can create a temporary administrator account (e.g., ANONYMOUS with password MileSt0ne2@16 or _DomainUser_ with Dom4!nUserP4ss) to launch a new instance and then delete the account. FBI20111024 variants include process listing/termination capabilities. COLDSTEEL can also modify registry keys (e.g., adding a service description), delete files, create processes with tokens, and signals readiness via hardcoded response codes (e.g., remote desktop ready, reverse TCP shell ready).

objects.name: Ahnlab
objects.description: An industry source referenced by the report for prior coverage of COLDSTEEL.

objects.name: Fortinet
objects.description: An industry source referenced by the report for prior threat research; the report cites Fortinet in relation to Log4Shell-related activity.

objects.name: Oreans
objects.description: Vendor referenced in the report as the developer of the Themida software packer used to obfuscate COLDSTEEL.

objects.name: T1059.003
objects.description: COLDSTEEL can run arbitrary commands using cmd.exe.

objects.name: T1569.002
objects.description: COLDSTEEL executes malicious code as a Windows service.

objects.name: T1543.003
objects.description: COLDSTEEL creates an autostart service to persist after a system reboot.

objects.name: T1190
objects.description: COLDSTEEL is believed to have been deployed following exploitation of Log4j.

objects.name: T1027.002
objects.description: MileStone2017 variants of COLDSTEEL have been observed to be packed using Themida as described in Defence Evasion (Themida).

objects.name: T1112
objects.description: COLDSTEEL modifies registry keys directly to add a description to its service.

objects.name: T1070.004
objects.description: COLDSTEEL has the ability to delete files from the infected machine.

objects.name: T1134.002
objects.description: The MileStone2016 variant of COLDSTEEL has the ability to create a process as the user named ANONYMOUS.

objects.name: T1082
objects.description: COLDSTEEL collects a range of system information from the infected machine.

objects.name: T1083
objects.description: COLDSTEEL has commands to enumerate the filesystem.

objects.name: T1057
objects.description: FBI20111024 variants of COLDSTEEL have the ability to collect process information.

objects.name: T1095
objects.description: COLDSTEEL communicates over TCP sockets, using a custom message format.

objects.name: COLDSTEEL_service_strings
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
rule COLDSTEEL_service_strings
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "Identifies the service created by COLDSTEEL."
        date = "2023-01-31"
        hash1 = "a94ed3d673261d62f2959979272d8c8d17e6e7f3"

    strings:
        $ = "msupdate"
        $ = "Microsoft Update"
        $ = "Enables the download and installation of Windows updates. If
this service is disabled, this computer will not be able to use the
Automatic Updates feature or the Windows Update Web site."

    condition:
        all of them
}

objects.name: COLDSTEEL_rundll32_use_and_export_names
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
import "pe"
rule COLDSTEEL_rundll32_use_and_export_names
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "Execution method used by COLDSTEEL."
        date = "2023-01-31"
        hash1 = "a94ed3d673261d62f2959979272d8c8d17e6e7f3"

    strings:
         $ = "rundll32.exe \"%s\",UpdateDriverForPlugAndPlayDevicesW"

    condition:
        all of them
        and pe.exports("UpdateDriverForPlugAndPlayDevicesW")
        and pe.exports("ServiceMain")
        and pe.exports("DiUninstallDevice")
}

objects.name: COLDSTEEL_strings
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
rule COLDSTEEL_strings
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "COLDSTEEL strings"
        date = "2023-01-31"
        hash1 = "a94ed3d673261d62f2959979272d8c8d17e6e7f3"

    strings:
        $ = "MileStone201"
        $ = "%SystemRoot%\\System32\\svchost.exe -k "
        $ = "%s SP%d"
        $ = "Win 2003"
        $ = "Win 98"
        $ = "RegSetValueEx(Svchost\\krnlsrvc)"
        $ = "RegOpenKeyEx(Svchost)"
        $ = "RegSetValueEx(ServiceDll)"

    condition:
        7 of them
}

objects.name: COLDSTEEL_Themida_useage
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
import "pe"
rule COLDSTEEL_Themida_useage
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "COLDSTEEL Themida import usage."
        date = "2023-01-31"
        hash1 = "9ec69a042106fc9d27a27197d3b680b468bca9a0"

    strings:
        $ = ".themida"
    condition:
        all of them
        and pe.exports("ServiceMain")

  and pe.imports("CloseServiceHandle", "ADVAPI32")
  and pe.imports("CreateEnvironmentBlock", "USERENV")
  and pe.imports("CreateWindowExA", "USER32")
  and pe.imports("SHGetFileInfoA", "SHELL32")
  and pe.imports("SelectObject", "GDI32")
  and pe.imports("WTSQuerySessionInformationA", "WTSAPI32")
  and pe.imports("strcspn", "MSVCRT")

}

objects.name: Log4j
objects.description: COLDSTEEL is believed to have been deployed following exploitation of Log4j.

objects.name: Analisi Malware: Coldsteel
objects.description: This report contains technical analysis and indicators associated with malware. coldsteel.
